case_title: ALLE'NORA BEAUTY SALON AND PARLOUR through Partner and others vs Mrs. QURAT-UL-AIN MANSOOR and others
appellant: ALLE'NORA BEAUTY SALON AND PARLOUR through Partner and others
complaint_summary: Dispute over ownership and exclusive rights to the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA' between the appellant and respondent.
investigation_summary: The respondent established prior use of the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA' since 1990 in Lahore and registered it in Class 44 effective from 29.07.2006. The appellant commenced use in 2002 in Karachi and filed for registration in 2006, claiming use since 2002.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the respondent's prior use and exclusive rights to the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA' in Pakistan. The appellant was restrained from using the trade mark.
punishment: Appellant restrained from using the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA'.
legal_arguments: Appellant argued lack of knowledge of respondent's prior use.
Appellant claimed geographical distance between Karachi and Lahore diminished likelihood of confusion.
Appellant argued 'ALLE'NORA' is generic and incapable of registration.
Respondent established prior use and registration of the trade mark.
citations: 1946 R.P.C. 3 (Office Cleaning Services v. West Minister Window and General Cleaners)
2015 CLD 1245 (Farooq Ghee and Oil Mills v. Registrar of Trade Marks)
witnesses: Mrs. Fozia (Examination-in-chief in Suit Nos.1510/2006 and 625/2007)

witness_statement.Mrs. Fozia: Appellant offered Rs. 250,000 to purchase respondent's business in 2003.

key_issues: Prior use of trade mark 'ALLE'NORA' in Pakistan.
Exclusive rights to the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA'.
Geographical distance as a defense in trade mark disputes.

maxims.Trade Mark Protection: Protection against confusion, deception, and fraud.

legal_terms.Concurrent Use: Simultaneous use of a trade mark by different parties.

words_and_phrases.ALLE'NORA: Trade mark disputed between appellant and respondent.

summary_vector_notes: The Sindh High Court dismissed appeals filed by ALLE'NORA Beauty Salon and Parlour against Mrs. Qurat-ul-Ain Mansoor regarding the trade mark 'ALLE'NORA'. The court upheld the respondent's prior use since 1990 and exclusive rights to the trade mark, restraining the appellant from its use. Arguments of geographical distance and honest adoption were rejected.
